turns.words: All right. Good evening, everyone.
Good evening.
Good evening.

[inaudible] our next session of story time, storytelling, and we going to talk about the COVID experience, okay? You have a little notebook in front of you, you can use to scratch little notes on. Let me explain to you that we're going to use [inaudible] instead of your names, so please use the tags to call. If you have to talk to someone else, please use their tags to call their name. Okay? Thank you for joining, this is a community conversation with the Public Health Corps storytelling project, I'll start by sharing some information about our purpose today, and your role in this conversation and project. First, let me just introduce myself. I'm Reverend Valerie Grant-Martin, I'm with Wholly Fellowship Ministry. What I've come in to help work are with project hospitality, and I'm delighted to be doing this. Now your name?
Nan.
And you are?
Ernest.
Welcome aboard, Nan and Ernest. And you are?
Georgina.
No, pseudo.
Welcome aboard Gigi, as you have changed-
Gigi, mm-hmm.
... your name-
I'm sorry. Thank you for reminding me.

Now, welcome aboard, and thank you for joining. Let me continue here, we're almost 2.5 years into the pandemic and the struggle around accurate, reliable, and trusted information sources is still real. You may often find yourself being pulled into different directions, feeling confused or in doubt when trying to evaluate which information to trust or make decisions that concern your own wellbeing and the wellbeing of the people you care about in your family and your community. The initiative you're joining today aims to change that. This conversation is part of an ongoing culminating power initiative called The Public Health Corps, a city-wide effort with a mission to expand the public health workforce by partnering with community groups and community health workers to eliminate COVID-19 inequities through outreach and education. The stories and experiences you share will become a part of the city-wide story library that amplifies the experiences of community members navigating the COVID-19 pandemic. We are recording the audio of today's conversation and the video portion of the conversation will be immediately discarded. To protect your confidentiality, we ask that you share only your first name and your voice. If you have additional privacy concerns, you have the option to remain anonymous by using a pseudonym. If you'd like to use a pseudonym or alias, please change your Zoom name to your desire, and this is only for the people on Zoom, and we're doing Zoom today. We encourage you to share your stories and experiences openly and to respond to all the questions, but keep in mind that you may choose not to answer a question at any time, that's if you don't feel like you are comfortable answering. Before we begin, I'm going to read a consent statement and ask you ... And you already signed, so we don't have to read the consent statement, because you already did this in-person. Okay? So the recording is on and we going to ask the participant. As a participant in this conversation you are providing consent to the New York City Public Health Corps to use the recording. This is what you'll find, okay? First question. If you understand and agree to this ... No, I'm sorry. I have to move on, this is just for the people who are on Zoom. First question, and please feel free, if you don't feel comfortable, remember, you do not have to answer, but we'd love you to share whatever information you can, and as open as possible. Okay? What COVID-19 resources have been most helpful for you during the pandemic, and why? Go ahead, Nan.

It was the support we received from not-for-profit organization, like Community Health Action, they were very much involved. They were [inaudible] giving emotional and mental support and mental health, they were providing masks and sanitizer. At the time, we couldn't even find it on Amazon or anything, so this really made a difference because it was a time when we were so scared even to go out. I remember I was a scared even to talk to anybody. So even going to the supermarket across the street, I remember I spent about four weeks at home, I will never leave the house. So it made a difference for me, all those people who were providing services and bringing cooked food, and bringing these boxes of produce and sanitizers. So this was the initial impression of the role of not-for-profit organization during that time. Project Hospitality, they were delivery food pantries. They were available all the time and they were sending boxes to everybody at home. So I had the social worker calling me twice from Project Hospitality, a week, just for mental support, because I remember I was so scared. That every time we talked of our families it was like saying goodbye because we did not know if we are going to make it or not.
Mm-hmm. You didn't know. [inaudible] mm-hmm.
Yeah. It was a tough time. There was really fear and this scared, and like horror. The horror of something unseen, but you can see all the effects of it at the larger scope.
That's correct. That is correct. Thank you so much for sharing that. Anyone else have something to say about that [inaudible] question?

Also, yes, as she said, the Community Health Action programs were very helpful to us. They were sending us food, and test kits, and produce as well. They were very kind and calling us every day, checking upon us, usually twice a day, or making sure we were okay. Fever kits and ... Yeah. It was a very, very hard time to get through. My wife and I, we were infected with it January 11th, and-
What year?

'21, and it was very hard times. The fever was unbelievable, and the coughing was unbelievable. It was very uncertain if we were going to make it through the next day. We had family members that was also infected by the pandemic, by coronavirus, and we were very worried about them as well. But, again, yes, the community did reach out to us every day, and Project Hospitality was a big part of it as well. They did, very much so, help us through the pandemic, at its hardest points.
Thank you. Thank you so much for sharing that, Ernest. Anyone else?
You're getting very emotional, recalling it.

It was ... The repercussions of being very sick was the main thing, but I lost my job, and on something that I've been working ... I've been working since I was 13, I'm in my 60s. Love my job, but they shut us down so fast. It was dentistry, and I'm the manager, and it was rough because I had to tell staff that this is what's going on. The thing that was so weird was that the building that we worked in, we also shared a space with a oral surgeon. So in the beginning of this all, because patients were calling, we were shut down. They said, "You cannot see any patients," the only thing we could do was call in prescriptions, as long as they were one of our patients so that we would know what they were not allergic to, and so on, and so on. It was difficult because there were people panicking, but they were calling doctors, but they were calling us thinking that they could come in. We were like, "I'm sorry ..." We had to stop answering the phone, and we would just check the messages. Every day there would be 30 or 40 messages, and it was people in emergency situations and they told us, "Do not send them to the hospitals." So the oral surgeon, because again, we shared this with other dentists, he was allowed to be open, but the thing was is he was sending patients to us and we were like, "We're closed." We went in every week for three days a week, to check. We had messages up to the hundreds. There was nothing we could do. We couldn't call in prescriptions because it could be someone wanting pills that ... That was illegal. We couldn't do it. So it was hard. It was hard, but when things finally got better and we had patients, you know ... But they shut us down so fast it wasn't funny. But all we could do was go in part time, check the messages, and they were always, "I'm in pain." "I'm in pain." But you have to be careful because it could've been somebody who just was on pills not for pain but for fun. So, anybody that we said had to do this and this, anybody that said, "Oh, oh okay, that's all right," they would hang up, we knew that that's what they were ... They were addicts looking for pain medication. But it was weird. I have been in that business over 30-something years and it was hard because I've been a patient myself in dentistry, so to speak, before it got very different, like it is now. I mean, I was telling people I've had fillings done with no anesthetic. They were like ... I said, "Yes. They didn't do it like that back in the day." I'm in my 60s, so you know? But it always made the patients feel better because I was good with that, but at the same time, I miss the patients. Met a lot of seniors that didn't come back and we were like, "Oh, I hope they're still with us." Because they're family, and I was with this doctor 30-something years and if wasn't there they'd go, "Where's Georgina?" "Where's Georgina?" You know, "She's out to lunch," or something. But we lost a few people, quite a few people. And then, when it was-
Thanks so much for sharing. I know it's not easy to-
Yeah. I'm sorry. I'm sorry.
... go back.
And also to have it, too. Yeah.
I know sometimes it's even better to get it out.
Yeah, mm-hmm.
And this is one of the reasons I think this project is important. All right?
Exactly.
Yeah, it is very important [inaudible].
Yeah, because we've lost people-
Yes.

... and that was family. Relatives and friends. You just, it's like, "Wow." I hate to say this expression, but it was kind of like thinning out the herd, so to speak. It was like, "What is going on?" What is going on?"
Yeah. It was a beyond definition feeling.
Exactly. Exactly.
That is so true. So does anyone else ... Do you have something to share, Amal?
Yeah, Amal, she was telling me before we started-
Please identify what you're doing for Amal, for the sake of the [inaudible].
Okay. Amal is a friend of mine, and she's speaks English, but not much, so she asked me to translate.
What other language does she speak?
She speaks Arabic.
Okay, so you're interpreting for her?
Arabic. [inaudible].
We are friends too.
Okay, what I would like her to do is to speak in Arabic what she wants to say, and then you can tell us what she said.
Okay. So, [Arabic]-
I didn't say my name.
You said Georgina [inaudible].
People call me Gigi.
You said Georgina.
You said Georgina.
Did I?
[Arabic].

Mm-hmm. Okay, so Amal's experience was different because when COVID hit she was in Egypt, visiting her family. So they stopped all the travel arrangements, so there was no travel. So she was stuck in Egypt.
And she lives in New York?
She is from New York. She lives here, a couple of blocks away from you.
Oh, okay. Very good. Oh.
So she went to Egypt, but when we are talking about resources and the government assistance, and the not-for-profit, there was none in Egypt. Absolutely none. Even you have to pay for the mask.
That's interesting.

They have to pay for everything. And people, she said that they were dying left and right. They did not stop going to churches and mosque, but they reduced the attendance, like only one person would sit on one seat. In other areas, where the very, what you call them? The underprivileged population is, or poor neighborhood, there was absolutely no awareness whatsoever about it. Like here, you could hear awareness on TV, on the news, and everywhere you go about this-
Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. All day long, mm-hmm.
Yeah. Yes.
So over there, there was nothing-
Wow.

... and people were really going to each other, they say, "Oh, there is a curfew." But the curfew, but people were gathering 20, 30 people in one place. Just the curfew was in the street but it wasn't indoor. So there were a lot of people dying after that because they were doing weddings and gatherings. They really didn't understand the wider spectrum of what was going on.
So they didn't have any help from any ... Like what we have here in New York, or US.
No. [Arabic]. Nothing, nothing. No help whatsoever.
So that leads me to the next question. This is for everyone, if you don't mind sharing first, Amal?
Mm-hmm.
What challenges did you have finding and using resources intended to help you with COVID-19?
Okay. So they were raising awareness on TV and on social media about protecting yourself, and stay away from the-
[Arabic].
Public areas?

So, don't go to mosque, don't go to churches. No weddings, no gatherings, no [inaudible]. So they closed the schools and the universities, so nobody was going there. There was no help, no food distribution. There was no assistance. Basically, we were giving you the information and you are on your own.
Wow.
How long did she have to stay ... How long did you have to stay in Egypt during the pandemic?

Yeah. She had to stay a year-and-a half, she and her husband, because there was no air travel. Anybody who was coming from different countries, they were putting in quarantine for 15 days. So they were staying in hotels at the beginning, for two weeks, on the government-
[Arabic].
Yes, and the flying to Egypt was free. So gratis, so there was no tariff for the air travel for the people who wanted to go home, because you know a lot of people were sent back home.
Oh, okay, yeah. Oh.

You know, a lot of Egyptian people, they work overseas. [Arabic]. So during that time, so they had to send everybody home because companies were closing down and there was no work, and no housing for them because they were not working, right?
[inaudible].
Start the [inaudible]. It's coming.
One question I would like to ask, and I'm going off of what is here right now because I'm interested and I think everybody would like to hear that-
I thought this was interesting though, yeah.
Yes. Very, yes.
Somebody who was from outside the United States.

Yes. Amal, since you had to stay in Egypt for over a year-and-a-half, how did you manage, when you get back, to pick up the pieces, with a mortgage, or rent, or the expenses that were being incurred here while you were away?

Okay. So during that time they were staying with his brother. So there was no work, because the family works together, and the whole business ... [Arabic]? Okay, so basically, everybody was staying home, nobody was working, nobody was generating any dollar because they were in business for themselves. They didn't even have food stamps or anything, and everything was skyrocketing. They didn't know about food pantries.
No, I'm talking about here in New York.
That's what I'm talking about.
Yeah?

Yeah. She came here, so she didn't have any food stamps. She was staying with her brother-in-law. Basically, their entire family were staying together because there was nobody working, no money, and [inaudible]-
That was us.
Yeah. Fell into that same position.
Oh, my gosh.
She didn't know about food pantries. She hasn't been here in the United States for a long time. She came to United States only five years ago.
Oh, okay. Mm-hmm.
So she is new to the United States.
Okay.

She didn't know about resources and benefits, and I don't know whatnot, but I remember when there was no work, I think her husband applied for pocket assistance, which is hardly anything. They didn't even qualify for food stamps because they were not in the city for five years yet.
Right.
Oh, my gosh.
Yeah. So it was like really very tough time. Very tough.
Okay. So the next question.
Does this answer your question?
Yes. Very good, thank you for sharing that. I know that must be tough, going back, but thank you so much for sharing.
Thank you.

Anyone else want to answer that second questions, about what challenges did you have finding and using resources intended to help you with COVID-19? Please, try and turn those off [inaudible]. Thank you. Anyone else want to answer that question? Remember, you don't have to if you don't want to.
I remember, if you don't mind, [inaudible]? It was March 13th when they closed the schools, it was a Thursday.
I remember that day because that's the day I decided to stop sending my children to school.

Yeah. So it was a Thursday and they decided to shut down the schools. I used to work then, part-time, in the tourism industry. I was a consultant. So you know tourism? It was Monday and I had an assignment to do. I called the company and I said, "They shut down the city. Am I supposed to go and do that assignment?" And they said to me, "Yes." At 11:00 AM they said to me, "Go back home, we just shut down." So the tourism industry, until now, it still did not recover. We still don't all these boats and all these cruises that was going on. So, until now, you are getting local people. We're still not getting international people coming and visiting. So the whole industry basically collapsed. So it was a tough time. It was a tough time to see, "When I'm going to go back to work?" The uncertainty of what was going on ... What was the question here?
What challenges did you have finding and using resources intended to help you with COVID-19? We're talking about during the pandemic.

Yeah, this was during the pandemic. There was a lot of resources. I still remember during that time there was a lot of clothes drive for Thanksgiving, for Christmas, for I don't know whatnot. We used to do volunteer work, we used to help a lot, and go everywhere and trying to help. So people who knew, got what they needed, but not so many people knew what was going on. So if you were a part of an organization, you got the resources, but a lot of people were not in programs and they did not know about these resources.
That's very interesting. Very, very interesting, [inaudible]. That is true.
Yeah. Sometimes we found in the supermarket some resources, contacts. I appreciated the people that, when we were all hiding at home somebody else was doing what they had to do.
Exactly.
This what made me very appreciative for those people who were not afraid, were not fearing-
Mm-hmm. Who were there, mm-hmm.

... like we're did. We were like crumbling inside ourselves at home, and somebody else was picking up the tab and doing the job. So I was very grateful for those hospital workers, for the supermarkets, the [inaudible] workers, the healthcare industry. And the pantries, all those volunteers that are not even getting paid for it.
The pantries, yeah.
Yes. Yes.
I appreciated all the people who sacrificed themselves for us while we were hiding and shutting down.
That is so true.
Port Richmond, they had a pantry out there. They were very, very kind to everybody. They really helped out a lot.
I believe that's Project Hospitality.
Mm-hmm.

Yeah, across from Faber Park. In my situation, we were working right up into the point where they was closed down. I'm a carpenter. Two of our clients had passed away beforehand. One of our clients who was getting ready to start working on their apartment, the lady passed away. She was a younger woman, I believe she was in her 40s-
Wow.

... and she suddenly passed away. Then a person that apartment that we just finished working on, he passed away. So we were wondering, "Who's next?" We were working right inside of their apartment. So it was very scary. A couple of my friends, they were sick prior to the pandemic, before the coronavirus really spread the way it did worldwide. Some of my friends I was speaking with, they said, "I'm sick and I've never been this sick before in my life." Prior to when they had the shutdown, a lot of people were passing away without knowing what was going on, before they had any information.
That is so true, mm-hmm.

Yeah, okay. So I want to go to the third question in this section, if anyone else has anything to say about that second question? If not, we're going to go to the third one. Who can help address these challenges, and how? The challenges we faced during that time, who do you believe can help with these challenges, and how can they help?

You know, awareness basically defeated those challenges, because I remember people were getting sick and they were afraid to go to the hospital because they said, "If I go to the hospital, I'm going to die."
Yes.

I remember, the beginning of the COVID I was as sick as a dog for two-and-a-half months, and I'm positive that it was COVID. There was no question about it. The feelings, the things that I felt, it was beyond definition. It wasn't the regular flu.
Flu. Yes. Yeah.
No, it wasn't. It was totally different. I was sick for two-and-a-half months and, believe it or not, there was no medication, no nothing. There was no testing.
I know, me too. Mm-hmm.

So I had a Z-Pak at home, and my doctor send me some steroid, and stuff like that, because I'm asthmatic. So I had to take two course, or three courses, of prednisone, and I was not recovering. Eventually, I made it. I remember, in July of 2020, I was preparing lunch and, all of a sudden, I start having heart palpitation. Unbelievable. When I took my blood pressure, so my heartbeat was like 170 and my blood pressure was 174/110, which is unusual.
Yes.

Mine, usually, is 60/110, and my heartbeat is usually 60, 62. No more. I felt there was something wrong with me, and for three hours it was not going anywhere. I was debating, I was so scared. Should I first stay home and die there, or should I go to the hospital and seek help?
Oh, my God.

I'm scared, how I'm going to go to the emergency room with all that death and all these trucks that they were carrying all these bodies. It was frightening. It as frightening. Eventually I said, "If I'm going to die, I'm going to die. So you need to go to the emergency room." So I called a car and they took me to the emergency room. Sure enough, I stayed two nights in the hospital and I did not contract any COVID. Although, people telling me was the other pavilion of the hospital was devoted to COVID and they had a different entrance. So there was a precautions. There was awareness. But people need awareness, it's very important to defeat those challenges. Because if people don't know, people who were dying, having heart attacks, and they were afraid to go to hospitals. People were having strokes and they were afraid to go to hospitals. So I start telling people, "If you are sick, you need to go to the hospital. Nothing happened to me, I went to the hospital and I came out one piece." I was diagnosed with SVT, which is like hyperventilation of the upper chamber of the heart, that comes out of nowhere. I had to go probably twice within three weeks to [inaudible] heart emergency ward.
Wow.

Yeah. I'm glad that I put my two cents together and decided to go to the hospital, because if I did not get that medicine that's going to slow my heart rate down, I would have had a stroke. So awareness is very important.
Yeah. Okay. Anyone else has anything to say about that question, who can help address these challenges and how?
Did I answer that question-
Yes.
Okay.
Thank you. Thank you for sharing.
You're welcome.

Being a survivor of it is myself, but I don't know if I had mentioned my younger sister, who was the school nurse. What happened was, she was at work and two of the kids, it was the break time they had, like lunchtime, and they get to hang out for a little bit. Anyway, one of the children came in and said this little girl just fell, out in the playground, she's bleeding. Of course, my sister drops everything, runs out there and picks up the little girl and brings her to her office. She calls the parents. The parents said, "Well, we're busy." Basically, they couldn't come and get her right away. Well, come to find out she had COVID. My sister got it from her. Of course, she didn't take anything out on the child, she found this out afterwards, but when she spoke to the parents, the mother said, "Well, I had to work." Can you imagine that she didn't even stop working to go and pick up her child? The thing is, is that little girl got how many other people, kids sick that day? You just think about it and go, "Wow." Again, both of us are survivors, but still. Whoo, it was rough, I'm much older. But this little girl was running a fever that was astronomical, and you still sent her in? Of course the children weren't wearing mask, like the adults, and such like that. But I don't know.
So you say responsibility is part of what would help then?
Exactly.
If everybody become more responsib-
Exactly. There were people who were like, "Well, I'm not going to get this." "I'm not going to get this."
Because a lot of people walk around with no mask on too.

Yeah, and they, "I don't have to do this." I'm like, wait a minute, aren't we all a team, so to speak? We're all in this together. You think you're not going to get it because, "I'm prettier than you," or, "I'm tall." I mean, honestly. I watched it, and like I said, just doing through dentistry, watching patients in agony. I mean real patients who couldn't come to see us, all we could do, like I said, was the prescriptions, and these were our patients, so they weren't faking it. But at the same time there were people like, "No, that's not going to happen to me," and they were the ones that were walking around giving it to everybody, and it's sad. I would watch, every day on TV, watching, I just couldn't help it, and the body counts, and how many more, and I'm like-
I can understand-
... "Doesn't that scare you enough?"
When you see what's happening, and if you're a responsible person, you're going to think about yourself, your family members, and your community.
Exactly.
So how do we do this? We don't rely on the government alone, it's up to us. You would think you going to protect yourself and your family and your community.
Exactly.
So, responsibility's [inaudible]-

Mm-hmm. But being so cavalier about it, "Well, I had to work." I did too. I had to work too, but somebody ... I got it, from my husband, he got it from somebody, and we did the right thing. But the way they were saying it was like, "I can't be bothered." I'm like, "Oh, my goodness."
You know, I strongly believe that some people were in denial.
Yeah. Mm-hmm. Yep.
They were in denial.
This thing was real.
"That's not me." "Oh, I think it's just ... I'll be over it by tomorrow."
And some people just didn't care.
Yeah, and that's it, right there. A lot didn't care.
Yeah. They just didn't care that they-
The parents of that little girl didn't care.

Until now, I have friends who are Republicans and they believe that this was the Obama thing. Like as if Obama created that pandemic, or that COVID, and, "I didn't know what was going on, I swear." Republicans, until now, they believe that this was Obama thing and they believe Obama is still controlling this country.
Oh, they're silly. What about our president talking about he went into the hospital, he had COVID, remember? That's when people were already starting to think something's not right with him-
It was, what's-his-name? Trump.
Yes, and then had the nerve to say, he came out the next day saying he was cured.
He was cured.
Yeah, but he never had it.
He never had it.
Unfortunately, we have to ... I [inaudible].
He never had it. I'm sorry. Sorry.
I want to kind of steer away from the politics a little bit.
Mm-hmm. Pardon me. Pardon me, I just couldn't help it though because-
I understand everyone's [inaudible]-
... liar. Sorry.
No, but I'm telling you this affects the mentality of other people though.
Yes. Responsibility. Responsibility's a key part here-
Yes. So they didn't decide that they're not going to go and get their cure, and they were really sick people out there. I mean mentally and physically.
So everyone answered the question accordingly.
Mm-hmm. Thank you.

The next thing we going to talk about is decision making processing with the vaccine. The vaccine experiences and the decision making. All right? Now I'd like to invite you to share how you made your decision about the COVID-19 vaccine. Can you describe a key moment that influenced your decision?
I can, actually.
And that's Gigi.

Yes. As a little girl, we had to get vaccinated just to go to school. You could not go into school ... You had to have that little booklet with all your shots and everything, and your arms would swell up and you were, the side effects, but you were not allowed to even go to school unless you had that book and showing your teacher. Your parents had it, and everything. The fact is, is the kind of thing is, the warnings were out many years back, so to speak. Now, again, it seems like this is happening again. I guess it comes through every so many years, or whatever. I don't know if it's a warning. I kind of get that feeling, and I'm like, "I'm not going to do that. No, I don't believe in that." But you could be a carrier and giving this to other people that haven't had it, maybe not just yet, but you know what I'm saying? That's the thing, and I don't think that they realize it. You could be a carrier and not even have the symptoms, or as bad, but you could be around people that get it and die, and that's because you had it and decided not to. That's your choice, of course, but to me, then you should stay home. Or just, basically, stay away from other people, because it's not fair-
So what prompted you? What really was the strong force behind you deciding that, "Yes, I got to take that vaccine."
The lives. The lives that were being lost.
Because ... Right. Right. Also, my mother was a nurse, God bless her, and I could not, in my heart ... I was like-
My mother was a nurse too.

I was like, "No, of course I'm going to go." Yes, I tested on my birthday, but ... A lot of stuff always happens on my birthday, unfortunately. Good stuff, but the thing was, was I just said to myself, I said, "You know, I'm feeling a little off." Watch TV every day because everything was shut down anyway, and the count started going, I was like ... And I knew what it was doing for my sister-
I went for a check-up and I said, "I don't feel too good."
... because she still had to handle that mentally as well. Yeah.

My nurse, she said, "Well, they're giving the vaccine right now outside of MetroPlus." She said, "You better go get checked." I went and got checked and I came back positive, and I made sure I got vaccinated as soon as possible, but it was too late. It was too late then, I already was infected.
When was that?
That was in January of 2021.
Yeah. Mm-hmm.
Yes.
And I went with him because I wasn't feeling great and I said, "You know what? I'm going to go. Something's telling me."
Yeah. It was right after New Year's.
Yep. Mm-hmm.

We got together with family and was with my sister-in-law, and we got over there and she says, "I don't feel too well, you all come in though." She was laying down. She had already been infected, and my nephew had already been infected. But there's key moments that led up to, definitely, making sure we were vaccinated, but it was too late. Vaccinated after we were already sick.

As soon as the vaccine became available, I said, "I'm taking it, no matter what." I said, "If I'm going to die, I'm going to die. So if I'm going to die with the precautions, it's better than dying without trying."
Right, exactly. To say, "At least I tried."
That's right. That's right.
Yeah.
That's what's I was telling other people, friends of mine. 'Oh, I don't ... I don't think." "No. No. You know what? I hate to say this, but-
You had people coming asking me, "Can I use your vaccination card?" "No."
Yeah.
Yeah, and [inaudible] people who were faking them.
Faking it, yeah.
Exactly.

But there was a lot of hocus pocus around [inaudible]. Remember the vaccine and the G5, and I don't know whatnot? People were scared, that people really thought that they were going to insert chips in their bodies [inaudible] vaccine.
Yes. Yes, yep.

This is why this conversation is so very important, so that we can make that decision about what we choose to believe and what we don't. We have people, unfortunately, who we didn't even expect to be at that level, say that they believe this thing is going to cause chips, and what have you.
My cousin.
Mm-hmm. A lot of people thought, they were just, "It's not going to happen to me." That's how they were thinking.
Let's hear from Amal. Amal, what prompted you to take the vaccine?

She said that she wanted to protect herself from dying because she has a very poor immune system. She is very, has a compromised immune system, and as soon as it became available, she didn't even give it a second thought, so she decided to take it.
Very good. Very good.
Look at that. Look at that, yes.
So, my cousin, and until now we still did not recover from her death, she lived in Germany. She and her husband. Highly educated people, and they didn't believe in vaccine.
There's a lot of people who don't.

Yeah. She didn't believe in the vaccine and she refused to take the vaccine. In January of this year, she was unable to breathe. She called the hospital, God bless America, there is no place like America. In Germany, they said to her just to stay home. She told them, "I cannot even breathe. If you are not going to take me to the hospital, I'm going to sue you." So they sent the EMS and they took her to the hospital. As soon as she got there, her lungs shut down, and they put her on a life support and her kidneys shut down. She was 70 days on a life support and, eventually, she passed away. She was 47 years old.
Oh, my gosh.
Sorry.
We did not recover from her death until now. If she took the vaccine ... But maybe it was her time? Who knows?
But see, then this is a lingering thought for the rest-
There is always if, if-
Yes. If, if. Then you, the family, has to deal with that because you're thinking [inaudible]-
Something about that vaccine though. I've had the vaccine and the boosters.
Yes, we've had that too.
Usually, during the summer months, I'll get a runny nose or some type of allergy. That vaccine, I haven't had no signs of catching a cold or anything. I don't know, that clean you out.
I took the first vaccine and the second-
Very interesting.
Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Both of us did, yes.
It is.

... and I took the booster, then I took the second booster, I believe. On the first day of July I was feeling sick for three weeks. I had all the typical symptoms, the classical symptoms of COVID, and I was testing negative. For three weeks I was as sick as a dog-
Mm-hmm, that happens.

... and there was no signs of COVID, because this [inaudible]. On the first day, you remember those tests you brought to the center? I took a box with me that day. I tested in the evening and it was a very fine second line. The next morning it was darker. By the evening, it was dark red. I was testing positive for 17 days. 17 days. Thank you for all these free tests that you gave us.
Wow.

Eventually, it went away. There was a lady, she was attending the adult day care center at the same time. We both tested positive in the same day, but I stayed home for 17 days and, I made sure, after I tested negative, for another seven days before I [inaudible]. This is what the doctor say to me, "After you test negative for seven days from the last test, then you can go and see your doctors and go back to your normal life." This lady, she had the COVID and two days later she was attending the adult day care center.
Huh.
So people need to be conscientious.
Yes.
People need to have a brain that, "I should not jeopardize somebody else's lives." This is an adult day care center-
Because they don't care ... Right.
... some people are in their 80s.
Yes. They're already compromised. Yes. Yes.
They have sense of responsibility, people need to have that sense of responsibility.

All right. Thank you so much for sharing. So we move on to the next ... Wait a minute, we're not done with this one as yet. It's key to keep your experiences personally. It has to be something that you experience directly, an experience that can help us understand what this decision making process was like for you. All right? Reflecting on this experience you just shared, what information or circumstances help you make that decision? Just identify one specific thing that made you make that decision.
Decision of what?
To take the vaccine.
To take the vaccine? So we're going back to the same-
One specific, just ... You mentioned, each person mentioned a series of things that happened, so give me one specific thing.

I could tell you one specific thing. One night I was, of course my wife was looking over me, I was coughing so bad, so bad, and I called my sister-in-law and my brother and I said, "Listen, I'm very, very, very sick." They said, "Maybe you should try the vaporizer," with the medicine that you put in?
Mm-hmm, the nebulizer.

Yeah. I had that in the room, and I don't know if it was too strong for me, but it overwhelmed me and, in my sleep, I could have sworn that I had burst, and my body went up and I was not on Earth anymore for a minute. I said, "This virus has taken me out." It totally felt like it had taken me out. The coughing was so bad, and between that and the nebu ... What do they call it?
Nebulizer.

Yeah, nebulizer, it did me in. I woke up out of it and I walked around a little bit in the house and got myself together, but in my dream, it finished me. So from that point, when I was able to get the vaccine, I was willing to take anything I could to stay on this Earth by that. I had never ... I've been sick, I've been hit by cars, I've had my bouts with cancer, I've had lots of loss in my life, but that virus is no joke.
Thank you for sharing that, Ernest. That was very brave of you to share.
Yeah.
Can anyone else just tell me one specific thing that prompted you to say, "Yes, I have to take that vaccine." I think Gigi-
Oh, I can see her, I'm sorry-

It's okay. No, no, that's okay. The thing is, for me not to do that, it would be disrespectful to my mother, who was a nurse. It would be the thing that she would say, in here she would be going, "You know you should've done this," and that's the thing. Also, to me, not to do it would be you want to go. Now that's different, you have a choice. But you do have a choice in this, whereas when they tell you, "It's too late, we can't help you," you don't have a choice anymore. But to do the right ... If you don't want to be here anymore, that's one thing, but think of your relatives and your people who love you, your partners, your best friend. It isn't just about you, There's a lot of heart there and love there, and I just, the whole point was do the right thing. You have a choice, you don't want to do it, that's fine, but I heard about some people who didn't do it and they're no longer with us.
So that's the one thing that prompted you to go ahead and?
Yeah.
That's good.
Also, like I said, my mother really like, "You better," you know?
Certain communities and neighborhoods, as we know, a lot of people ref-
They're poisoning us. "They're doing this-
Yeah, they poisoning us.
"They're doing this," and I can understand that. I can understand that as well, but I was like, "I'm going to take this chance, it's either die from that or die from not taking it."
One or another.
And there's people who love me and want me to still be here.
And you want them to be still here.
Exactly.
Thank you so much for sharing, Gigi.
Thank you.
For me, it was the briefing that Governor Cuomo was doing every single day, and he was saying, "We lost 100."
The briefing, yeah.
Yeah, I watched every day, right?
"We lost ..." [inaudible] seeing the endings going up every single day-
Mm-hmm, up and up. Yep.
... until one day, 1,000 people died in one day in New York City alone. You know what? Those briefing were very effective and really welcome to me.
Yes. Yes. We couldn't help it.
Oh, [inaudible].
When they were showing those bodies, body bags, coming out of from Queens Hospital and-
[inaudible].
... as soon as that vaccine became available I said, "I don't want to become a statistic, so I'm going to take it."
Thank you for that, thank you so much.
Yeah, absolutely. Watched every ... And she's right. It was like, "I'm not going to do it, I'm not going to do it." Then you see it, and the count and it's getting higher.
I was born in [inaudible] Hospital.

My sister, she was telling us, "You guys don't know half of it." She worked the night shift and the night shift was when most of them would go. I know what it did to her, it took a lot out of her and she's been a nurse for quite some time. But you know what I'm saying? She didn't come home telling us, we could just see it, what it was doing to her. But she's like, "This is my job, this is what I do." She loves her job, but still. Then the family relatives, she has to tell them, basically that this person passed, and so on, like this. So again, I understand people are afraid, but the other option is not to be here at all anymore. Yeah.
Mm-hmm. You're so right. Mm-hmm. So Amal, can you say what specific thing that prompted you to take that vaccine?

Yeah, okay. She says that all those people who died in Egypt when she was there really prompted her not to be a victim of COVID, and she was afraid that she might give, if she get infected with COVID, to give it somebody she loves and might, yeah, lose their lives because of her.

That is also ... Very good. Thank you for sharing, Amal. I really appreciate that. Okay, so we going to move on to the next item on the list. This one is role in community. I'd like to invite you to think, next, about your community and the role in it. Can you share a story or a experience about how the community organizations in your neighborhood supported you and your community during the pandemic?
I think you gave me one like this before and I filled it out, right?

[inaudible]. Yes, yes. So now briefly, because I believe some people already spoke about the community, so just briefly reiterate what you said before about how the community organizations helped you. All right?

Some people don't understand the role of not-for-profit organizations. It's not like when we are having problems we go to them. Sometimes those not-for-profit organization, they are picking up what the city can't do, or the state can't do, or the government can't do. Yes, they get funding, but they had a vital role in delivering the services that's needed in the community. So I believe that they had a very vital role during the pandemic, and they really went above and beyond to help people, sacrificing themself. It was food delivery, food pantry, even your medication was delivered to you and you were like cocooning in your home protecting yourself-
Absolutely.
... while somebody else did not even care about themself. This was like, they're not-for-profit organization-
Yeah, it was fantastic.
That they were doing awareness and they were going everywhere. Going to hospitals and trying to help, and volunteering.
They took risks as well.
Oh, my God, they [inaudible]-

Yeah, they were delivering food ... I'm sorry, not to cut you off. Pardon me. They were delivering, because we were eligible, being home sick, they were delivering food to the house. They would just knock on the ... Remember, babe?
Mm-hmm.
And it was sitting there and they were like, "Are you feeling ..." That was wonderful. It was truly wonderful, but excuse me for cutting you off.
No. No, no, no, please just go ahead.
A lot of people stepped up.
Absolutely. Absolutely.
Yes.

That was the thing, a lot of people stepped up. I thought it was fantastic. It was unfortunately a sad issue to be doing it, but there were people there. There were people there for you. Even if you thought you were alone, they weren't. They had all kind of thing ... They jumped to it quick, too. They called in the army, so to speak.
Like all these restaurants that they redirected their services to provide food for the hospitals and for the workers-
Yep. Exactly, and the workers. Yes.
The sanitation workers. They were not getting anything out of it. They just jumped, without thinking, to help.

Yeah. Who was our friend that was playing the music for them too? Remember? There was this DJ, he started playing music for, because they're all coming out from being there like 12 hours. Remember? It was pretty nice, it was soothing music, and such, he was playing it outside the hospitals.
Oh, yeah. Yeah. Mm-hmm.

I was so touched, and I wasn't there but I was like, "Aw." He's like, "I know you just did a long stretch," and my sister was one of those people coming out because she worked the night shift ... They wanted the most experienced ones at night, who could handle it more too-
There was a lot of heroes and angels.
Yes, mm-hmm.
Absolutely. Can I ask that question to Amal?
Yes, please.

In Egypt?
In Egypt.
In Egypt.
Oi.
She said no services whatsoever.
My goodness.

You couldn't find toilet paper or anything.
Oh, yeah.
[inaudible]. That's really interesting.
So she said [inaudible], so there was not even-
That's true, that's true, ran to the supermarket too. Yeah, groceries [inaudible]. Remember? We were like, "We got to stock up, they're shutting everything down."
[inaudible]. Everything jumped 10 times the real price [inaudible].
Wow, yes. Price [inaudible].
So there was a lot of exploitation there and a lack of services.
That's so cruel.
And no government support. So the government was just giving you the advice-
Yep, yep. Hands-off, mm-hmm-
So this is why I always say God bless America. We are really spoiled in this country.
Did she have to pay for the vaccine there? Did people have to pay for the vaccine there?
No, there was no vaccine when she came, she took the vaccine here in the United States.
Oh, so when she left there the vaccine was not available there?
[Arabic]. If corona started '20, it must.
Oh. [Arabic].
Okay. She said during that year-and-a-half when she was in Egypt, there was no vaccination. So she-
[Arabic].
Nan?
Yes?
[inaudible], do you have something playing around here?
Oh, this is the call for prayers, the Islamic prayer.
Oh, it's [inaudible]. Okay, so we just-
[inaudible] just went off now. It went off, be back towards the [inaudible].
I apologize.

So, no, she said when they were there for a year-and-a-half, [inaudible] I had to remind her that she, there was no vaccination. No vaccination. So a year-and-a-half into the COVID and there was no vaccination in Egypt.
Wow.

So when she came to the United States, so she took the vaccine, and this is when she said, "I didn't want to give it to somebody I love," because when she went back to Egypt, back in, she went in December and she spend a few months there, she said she was vaccinated when she went. It was free. I think the United States sent a lot of vaccination to Egypt.

That's very good to hear, thank you so much for sharing that, Amal. So the next question of how did these community organizations impact decisions related to COVID-19 vaccinations in your neighborhood?

I remember Community Health Action, when they start having the testing they said, "We are having testing, do you want to test?" Because I was sick, remember I told you? They made an appointment for me, so I went and I tested negative. So there was no incoming bodies then, they were not doing the incoming bodies when they started. Then few months later they called me and they said the vaccine is available for your ... Because they were giving it to groups of people, like the vulnerable, like I'm asthmatic, obese. So they made an appointment for me and I did not hesitate. As soon as she said to me, "I will make an appointment for you," I jumped into it.
Very good.

So it was Community Health Action, basically. They were really carrying the flag. Because they have a clinic, and we were going to that River, very first spring ... what is it, that clinic on Bay Street?
I know where you're talking about-
Yeah.
Me too, I'm just going blank here.
Yeah, 57 Bay Street.
I know exactly where you're talking about.

So they had a clinic, and I used to go to that clinic. So as soon the vaccine became available they were giving it to the people who were first, then they were spreading it to outside the community group.

Right. Okay. Anyone else can tell about how your community organizations impact decisions related to COVID vaccines in your neighborhood? Remember, if you find it difficult to answer, don't worry about it.
Mm-hmm. No, I was just wanted to say something what she was talking about. I was so happy when they had the vans where you could come-
Oh yeah, when they were doing a nose testing and everything.

Yes, and they were there on site instead of people who saying, "I can't get there," they were parked, they had them everywhere and you could go and get it done and come right out and come back to work, if you were on your lunch or something.
Right. On Broad Street.

Then they were giving you $100 to go and to be inoculated. So to save your life they're offering you $100, why wouldn't you go? Especially when you see the count every mor ... Well, I'm watching every morning-
I did it without $100, honestly.
But can you imagine though?
[inaudible] $100.
They were offering people that.
That was a plus.
I didn't even have a chance [inaudible]-
We were going anyway, we didn't even know that they were doing that, we just went to get it.
[inaudible] from Staten Island, if I wanted to pay for it over here myself. I had to go to Manhattan to get my-
Why?
Because-
Oh, you know what? The first vaccine, I took it in Brooklyn.
... you couldn't get an appointment. You couldn't get an appointment on Staten Island.
That's true.
Yeah.

People were coming from everywhere to Staten Island. We had many, many different sites. So I took the train and went to Manhattan and I got it there, my first and my second, and then by the time I was ready for the boosters it was ready, I was ready to do it on Staten Island. Yeah.
Mm-hmm. It was interesting though.

There was a lot of confusion, like the sites. That this site is Tuesday, this site is Wednesday, this site ... So once I had to go for testing and they sent me to Brooklyn. Can you imagine? Because there was nothing available here, you had to wait I don't know what-
People were coming from abroad. Overseas.
Right.
But not only that, they had it where they ... You could just walk in, you didn't have to have-
People took [inaudible]-
No, you couldn't just walk in.
Oh, no, no, you're right, but for those that, the long vans-
[inaudible] first time because I worked in worked at two sites on Staten Island as mental health provider.
... they just walk in. Yeah.

So I knew people coming in from different areas to take the vaccine. Most of the count that they did for Staten Island wasn't just Staten Islanders. It's people were coming from New Jersey [inaudible]-
Mm-hmm.
... just to take the vaccine. It was amazing to see how low it was.

So I took the Access-A-Ride to Brooklyn to get the test and, believe it or not, they said to me, "Oh. No, there is no testing site here." "Are you sure?" No, there was nobody. They gave me the address and the information and the phone number, so when we called the phone number they said, "Oh, we're sorry, we transferred it somewhere else." Where was that other place? It was about 25 minutes, by car, to go. So the guy, the Access-A-Ride driver, they supposed to drop you off and leave you. I said to him, "This is a deserted area, I don't know anybody here, and look, there is nobody in the street." He was so kind, he won't even leave me until I heard from them. I said, "I don't know where to go." It was his lunch break. Can you imagine? And he took me there, 25 minutes, 27 minutes I still remember, and he dropped me where I'm supposed to go. Then I had to call Access-A-Ride and they said to me, "Oh, we're sorry, we cannot." Because you know Access-A-Ride, they are very particular about location, and I don't know whatnot. Honestly, I don't know what happened then, it was like a miracle. I said, "I need to talk to the supervisor," and I told her, "This is what happened, what do you want me to do? I mean, I don't know where I am." She sent me a car. So there was a little confusion too.
Yes, in the beginning.
Yeah.

Remember, this was first for everybody. It was first for everybody, there were times when people go to certain sites for the first dose of the Pfizer, and when it came time for the second dose, they were furloughed to another area. So, it happened, but I still commended New York City's government. I commended the US for everything they were doing.
Oh, yeah. Oh yeah.
Oh yeah, they jumped it quick. They jumped on it quick.
Yes. I really feel strongly about how things went.
The mayor and the governor-
I don't believe it [inaudible].
Yeah, and reported every morning.
This [inaudible] was new to every one of us, but it did an amazing job. I don't care what anybody else says, I can tell you that.
Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Exactly.
They did an amazing job. There were people out there-
Yep, they didn't lie. They didn't try to cover anything, they were straight up. Yeah.

... I was preaching to the people and everybody was very satisfied about how things were going. I think I can say yes, in the middle of all what was going on, people stood together, the government did what they had to do. Their responsibility was key. Resources. To me, I can't complain. I can't. I didn't hear anybody complaining on my end.
No, and the free test, the not-for-profit organization, they were giving us the free test-
Exactly. Mm-hmm, and the shots.
... and they called me, they said, "You can come to this site between this hour and this hour and you can get a free test." So we are very grateful for that.
Yes.
Boxes. Like Project Hospitality, when people were going to pick up pantries they were giving them masks and sanitizers-
Yes. Yeah, I mean for the pantries, they were giving you enough food for a month. Yeah.
I'm honored to be with them, because this is what I love to do, and when I see people in need, I mean-
And Ms Troia, the director of Project, she was everywhere-
I can attest to that.
This lady was everywhere.

She was driving the U-Haul trucks, she was picking up food, making sure people got food. She didn't matter if it was five in the morning, six in the morning, she ... And I saw her, so I know what I'm talking about. The homeless people, she made sure everybody had something, a place to sleep and food to eat. That's a key factor in [inaudible].

So basically, for me, it was Project Hospitality, and Community Health Action. That they did most of the work. I don't know if any other ... I'm not familiar with many other not-for-profits on the Island.
Right.
Are you familiar with any?
There are some others that I could-
I know there is Catholic charities, but honestly, we did not hear from them.
Yeah. Mm-hmm.
They were there, they were there.
Oh yeah.
They were there, but you know?
At least I can say is that Project Hospitality partners with some of the other.
Okay.
Faith-based organizations like Wholly Fellowship-
The Salvation Army too.
Yes.
The Salvation Army, but not as much as Project Hospitality.

So there [inaudible]. There were others there, but the two major organizations did the best that they could do, and other people chipped in. The community itself, the hospital, I remember, RUMC, people were bringing food for the people who worked there. So it was amazing to see how people-
The volunteers.
Yes.

Mm-hmm. Yeah, what about the gentleman that was playing music? He was playing music for them because they worked that, they were doing triple shifts. My sister, she was doing like a day-and-a-half. And she had didn't want to travel the trains, it was starting to get crazy already then, but it was costing her $125 each way.
To Uber back and forth.

Yes, to take a car service safely, because she had to be there at a certain time, and of course ... Because they wanted the most experienced ones on that longer shift, so still though. Then they were playing music for them, this gentleman was playing beautiful music outside of the hospital. The workers are leaving-
People were bringing flowers, food, and PPEs-
Right, and food for them because they knew they couldn't get out. Where would they [inaudible], they had to be on site?
... dropped off, whatever people could find.
Exactly. I thought that was awesome.
[inaudible], a lot of things.
It was MakerPark. MakerPark made face mask and protective equipment for, yeah. They made-
People stepped up.
... like 5,000 face masks for the hospitals.
Yes.
Yes.
Those ladies, they were making them at home-
Yes.
[inaudible] any. The other thing that I didn't like, when they commercialize masks. So they were making them beautiful and fancy and exotic, and I don't know whatnot-
Yeah, fashionable.
Yes.
That's a common thing for people to do.
Yeah.
So this was-
The beaded ones were beautiful.
This was pandemic, people were dying and they were bedazzled.
Exactly. Exactly, "Look at this ..." Bedazzled is right.

Okay, so now let's think about the future, all right? I'd like you to reflect on how the pandemic continues to impact your community. What will a post-pandemic future look like in your community? A second thought I'll ask after that. Just think, when I said, "Post," after the pandemic. So the pandemic is gone, we still have COVID, don't get me wrong, COVID is still here, however, what do you think it will look like in your community?

Let's say that COVID really changed us forever. It was unfathomable experience, and knowing that it was international, that it touched everybody, nobody was immune and nobody was safe. Everybody was scared, in different languages, in different races, in different religion, it was just overwhelming experience. I think if we have another pandemic, people are more mentally prepared, I believe. So this was took us, by chance, it knocked us upside down. But I think now people more receptive if anything happens, so they will communicate better and cooperate better. Taking it from here now, to the future, we know how life is very valuable.
Right. Yes.

Life is very valuable, and one life lost is too much to lose. But there are people who paid their lives, and they were not lucky enough to have the vaccine ready when we had it, testing when we had it. So for those people, they unforgettable, they will be unforgettable. Ever, we are not going to forget them. We should have hope for the future. I'm glad that they did a lot of research in a very short time. The government dedicated so much fund to do the research and come up with the vaccine. So I'm very grateful for me.
Mm-hmm. Stepped up.
For me, this is the future. Research and science, and reception. People have to receive.
Right.
That's true. That's true. Anyone else?
I also believe that even though this was a hard, terrible time, it has brought ... What's the word I'm looking for?
Brought people together.

Yes, and their hearts, and it makes you kind of alive again, even though this is something ... It comes along. If you look back in certain times, it's something like this, something horrific has to bring us back together again so that we're still human and that we still have hearts. As I was saying, I was watching every day, and praying for people and it's like, "Oh, God, please." But at the same time, everybody I knew was doing this too, they were like ... And even though it was breaking my heart, I just, I cared. I cared enough to watch, and to listen. We both did. It was like, "God, bless them. Peaceful journey." The thing is still, and the numbers, it was like, "Oh, gosh," but at the same time, the fact that they d ... Someone was saying, "Oh, you know they're not telling you the truth." I think that was kind of enough of a truth, we can take the rest ourselves. At the same time, the fact that they were giving ... It was hard because I was like, "Stop telling me how many," because it was sad. But at the same time, it was information for everyone. So every morning, early, we had that TV on to just check in and see, and so on, like that. Because I know my sister was in the midst of that, being a nurse and such. But it took a lot out of her too. At the same time, she's a good nurse and she did her job. There were others who were like, "Oh no, I'm not going in," like that, but she was one of the senior nurses and so she did what she's supposed to do. A lot of good people did, that's why they had the guy out there playing the music for them, trying to, you know? Because could you imagine? You're listening to something wonderful after something so sad, losing another patient, and you're getting ready to leave and someone's playing some soft music for you to listen. I thought that was awesome.
That's [inaudible]-
It kind of brought us together.
... but in your community, and Gigi, you're in Stapleton, right?
Yes.

What would it look like in Stapleton for you in the future, the post-pandemic period. What do you think, comparing it to during the pandemic to getting out of the pandemic in the future? What do you think?

Wow, that there's more communication. I mean, we're very close with our neighbors, we've been there so long. I just think that, if people just would, talking to each other more or being more receptive of ... You know? These are people that live right next door to each you, and to, let's say, and you just walk right past me every day or whatever. That's your choice, of course, but I think that ... I don't know, I just think that when people are more hospitable to each other, and this is your neighbor. This is your neighbor, they live next door to you, whatever, whatever, and the point is we look out for our neighbors.
Yeah. I think it definitely bring humanity closer together.
Yeah. Then that's the thing, if you just show a little compassion. You don't have to put your heart on the table or whatever, like I do, I can't help it-
We've moved forward already, somewhat, but the way crime is at this point, it's har-
Yes.
Escalating.
Escalating, it is very-
